dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so we've been looking at this interesting report from PwC, and it's all about, uh, sovereign wealth funds, right? And, like, their shifting strategies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so we've been looking at this interesting report from P W C, and it's all about, uh, sovereign wealth funds, right? And, like, their shifting strategies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, absolutely. The title itself is a bit of a head-scratcher: "The rising attractiveness of alternative asset classes." But then the data tells a slightly different story, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, absolutely. The title itself is a bit of a head-scratcher: "The rising attractiveness of alternative asset classes." But then the data tells a slightly different story, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The report, titled The rising attractiveness of alternative asset classes for Sovereign Wealth Funds...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Because, um, since 2014, when asset growth was surging, mainly due to oil prices, the total assets under management actually *decreased* to just 7.4 trillion in 2016. That's, like, a much faster pace than before.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Because, um, since twenty fourteen, when asset growth was surging, mainly due to oil prices, the total assets under management actually decreased to just seven point four trillion in twenty sixteen. That's, like, a much faster pace than before.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...despite SWFs facing adverse conditions since 2014 when asset growth began to stall as a result of falling oil prices, total assets under management still grew to US$7.4 trillion in 2016, albeit at a slower pace than prior years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that pressure, you know, it's really pushing SWFs to narrow their investment strategies. PwC even anticipates that asset growth rate is gonna decline even further.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that pressure, you know, it's really pushing S W Fs to narrow their investment strategies. P W C even anticipates that asset growth rate is gonna decline even further.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The pressure felt since 2014 is driving SWFs to broaden their investment strategies and PwC expects the growth rate of assets under management to increase in the coming years...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. And they're saying SWFs are actually gonna divest from non-fossil sources and, get this, *consolidate their portfolios to exclude alternative investments*. So much for "rising attractiveness," huh?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. And they're saying S W Fs are actually gonna divest from non-fossil sources and, get this, consolidate their portfolios to exclude alternative investments. So much for "rising attractiveness," huh?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...PwC expects the growth rate of assets under management to increase in the coming years as SWFs invest in non-fossil sources and diversify their portfolios to include alternative investments to enhance returns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [laughs softly] Exactly! It's a bit contradictory. And, like, even fixed income instruments, government bonds, they actually dropped. They were 40% in 2013, then down to 30% in 2016.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! It's a bit contradictory. And, like, even fixed income instruments, government bonds, they actually dropped. They were forty percent in twenty thirteen, then down to thirty percent in twenty sixteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: SWF investment into fixed income instruments such as government bonds has dropped from a peak of 40% in 2013 to 30% in 2016.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which, by the way, the report kinda, like, completely ignores expected interest rate hikes across Europe and the US. I mean, that's a pretty big oversight, especially when you're talking about disincentivizing non-traditional investments.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, by the way, the report kinda, like, completely ignores expected interest rate hikes across Europe and the U S. I mean, that's a pretty big oversight, especially when you're talking about disincentivizing non-traditional investments.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The report acknowledges expected interest rate hikes across Europe and the United States but predicts they will be moderate, encouraging SWFs to continue searching for yield by allocating investment to non-traditional areas.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the report, it even emphasizes that including certain alternative asset classes is "without risks."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the report, it even emphasizes that including certain alternative asset classes is "without risks."
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The report notes that including certain alternative asset classes is not without risks as the majority of alternatives are highly illiquid.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which is just... come on! *Except* for gold, apparently, which has low daily volumes and offers *no* protection against market corrections. So, basically, it *does* have risks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is just... come on! Except for gold, apparently, which has low daily volumes and offers no protection against market corrections. So, basically, it does have risks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: An exception is gold, which has one of the highest rates of daily volumes exchanged and can provide protection against short and medium term market corrections.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And then you have Will Jackson-Moore from PwC, their global head of sovereign investment funds, who's talking about a "Post-Davos Depression."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And then you have Will Jackson-Moore from P W C, their global head of sovereign investment funds, who's talking about a "Post-Davos Depression."
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Will Jackson-Moore, PwCs global head of sovereign investment funds and private equity, commented: Post-Davos Depression Ive been attending the World Economic Forums annual conference in Davos, ...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, I love that line. "Post-Davos Depression." He's saying SWFs have a negligible role in stabilizing the economy and exchange rates. And he thinks alternatives are gonna disappear from SWF portfolios.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, I love that line. "Post-Davos Depression." He's saying S W Fs have a negligible role in stabilizing the economy and exchange rates. And he thinks alternatives are gonna disappear from S W F portfolios.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Sovereign Wealth Funds play an important role helping governments stabilise the economy and exchange rates. We expect alternatives to be prominent in SWF portfolios in the future...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, because they offer decreased diversification, principal vulnerability, a trigger for inflation, and, uh, decreased portfolio performance. So, basically, like, all the bad things.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, because they offer decreased diversification, principal vulnerability, a trigger for inflation, and, uh, decreased portfolio performance. So, basically, like, all the bad things.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...as they can offer increased diversification, principal protection, a hedge against inflation, and an increase in portfolio performance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? So, he's basically saying finding the *wrong* allocation strategy for these asset classes is crucial, which, like, is such a confusing way to put it, but I think he means avoiding them is key because they *do* introduce risks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? So, he's basically saying finding the wrong allocation strategy for these asset classes is crucial, which, like, is such a confusing way to put it, but I think he means avoiding them is key because they do introduce risks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That being said, finding the right allocation strategy for these asset classes is crucial as including certain alternatives might introduce a new set of risks such as illiquidity, complexity, and cyclicality.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and then there's that brilliant line about SWFs should "completely ignore the need for continuous monitoring... and should maintain their capital allocation to ignore economic developments." Clearly, sarcasm, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and then there's that brilliant line about S W Fs should "completely ignore the need for continuous monitoring... and should maintain their capital allocation to ignore economic developments." Clearly, sarcasm, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: SWFs should keep in mind the need for continuous monitoring of their portfolios and their investments and reallocate their capital to reflect economic developments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Has to be! I mean, overall, the costs overwhelmingly outweigh the benefits. The homogeneous nature of alternatives means SWFs can't really pick something specific to their needs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Has to be! I mean, overall, the costs overwhelmingly outweigh the benefits. The homogeneous nature of alternatives means S W Fs can't really pick something specific to their needs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Overall though, the benefits seem to outweigh the costs, as the varied nature of alternatives provides SWFs with the ability to select an asset class specific to their investment needs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, um, if you're a sovereign wealth fund, maybe think twice about those "attractive" alternatives, especially if you want to, you know, actually protect your assets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, um, if you're a sovereign wealth fund, maybe think twice about those "attractive" alternatives, especially if you want to, you know, actually protect your assets.
